questions.question_text: In order to connect between disparate OSPF and EIGRP portions of a network, mutual route redistribution has been configured. What are two disadvantages of doing this? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B are the correct answers.

Selected Answer: AB
A & B are correct

choices.B: Differing metrics between the routing protocols could result in sub-optimal routing.
choices.A: Prone to routing loops if not done correctly
choices.C: Route redistribution is not supported on most Cisco router platforms.

discussion.content: EIGRP adjacency requires matching ASN and K-Values.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Matching ASN is a must otherwise they won't become neighbors.

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

In this case D is right as networklessons is saying: 

Two EIGRP routers with the same router ID will still form a neighbor adjacency. 

So the only valid option is D.
Remember that the first to options are valid if we were talking about OSPF.
If the MTU does not match you will flap everytime in EXSTART/DOWN.
The timers must match also otherwise the neighborship will not come UP.

choices.A: Must have identical hello and dead timers
choices.C: Must have matching MTU’s on the physical network links that connect the routers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements are true regarding two EIGRP routers to become neighbors?
Which of the following statements are true regarding two OSPF routers to become neighbors? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B and C are correct. There are quite a few questions about OSPF being stuck in EXSTART, which is a typical symphtom of mismatching MTU. OSPF also needs matching hello and dead timers.

Selected Answer: BC
B & C are correct
just know that there is option of "MTU ignore". But given ans is correct.

choices.B: Must have identical hello and dead timers
choices.D: Need not be on the same subnet.
choices.C: Must have matching MTU’s on the physical network links that connect the routers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
You need to connect all OSPF areas to the backbone (area 0). If you can't do this the traditional way, you need to use a virtual link to connect them.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Typo? I assume it meant to say "Area 2 is used to connect area 1..." instead of area 1 to area 1. Given that, a virtual link is correct.

comments.content:
No it´s not a typo, since area 2 is connected only to area 1, which in turn is connected to the backbone area 0, area 2 is not directly connected to area 0. 
To achieve full connectivity, a virtual link is required to connect area 2 to area 0 through area 1.

questions.question_text: A new site has been added to an OPSF network using area 2. Area 2 is connected only to area 1 of this OSPF network. Area 1 is used to connect area 1 to the backbone area 0. Should you expect full connectivity to the networks located in area 2 from area 0 in this scenario?

choices.A: Yes, by default there will be full connectivity.
choices.D: Yes, but area 2 will need to be configured as a stub area.
choices.B: No, you will need to redistribute the area 2 routes into area 0.
choices.C: No, a virtual link is needed to logically connect area 2 info area 0.

discussion.content: RD is used to keep it unique when advertised throughout the VPN. Route target is used to control the import into the right VRF, the VRF being tied to a VPN via an RD.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A for sure

questions.question_text: Router R1 is configured using VRF’s to support customer VPN’s. Some customers are using the same private IP address space. Which of the following is used to ensure that these routes are unique when advertised throughout the VPN?
